messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 87 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Machine Learning for Electronic Design Automation: A Survey

Paper Abstract: Abstract. With the down-scaling of CMOS technology, the design complexity of very large-scale integrated (VLSI) is increasing. Although the application of machine learning (ML) techniques in electronic design automation (EDA) can trace its history back to the 90s, the recent breakthrough of ML and the increasing complexity of EDA tasks have aroused more interests in incorporating ML to solve EDA tasks. In this paper, we present a comprehensive review of existing ML for EDA studies, organized following the EDA hierarchy.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 87 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 87"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Intel HLS Compiler",
        "Xilinx Vivado HLS",
        "TensorFlow: A System for Large-Scale Machine Learning",
        "VLSI Placement Parameter Optimization using Deep Reinforcement Learning",
        "Built-In Test of RF Components Using Mapped Feature Extraction Sensors",
        "High-Definition Routing Congestion Prediction for Large-Scale FPGAs",
        "Learning To Solve Circuit-SAT: An Unsupervised Differentiable Approach",
        "Machine Learning-Based Pre-Routing Timing Prediction with Reduced Pessimism",
        "Neural Combinatorial Optimization with Reinforcement Learning",
        "Towards Mixed Analog/Digital Design Automation: a Review",
        "Michihiro Shintani",
        "Learning Evaluation Functions to Improve Optimization by Local Search",
        "Brayton and Alan Mishchenko",
        "LegUp: An Open-Source High-level Synthesis Tool for FPGA-based Processor/Accelerator Systems",
        "Vaishnav Srinivas",
        "Verification of Complex Analog and RF IC Designs",
        "Dennis J-H Huang",
        "Tianqi Chen and Carlos Guestrin",
        "Semisupervised Hotspot Detection With Self-Paced Multitask Learning",
        "RePlAce: Advancing Solution Quality and Routability Validation in Global Placement",
        "Janardhan Rao Doppa",
        "Christophe Kelma",
        "Discriminatory Analysis: Nonparametric Discrimination, Consistency Properties",
        "Automated Discovery of Local Search Heuristics for Satisfiability Testing",
        "Computer-Aided Design of Analog and Mixed-Signal Integrated Circuits",
        "Can Machine Learning Learn a Decision Oracle for NP Problems? A Test on SAT",
        "Sabine Süsstrunk",
        "Multilayer Feedforward Networks are Universal Approximators",
        "Coverage-Directed Test Generation Automated by Machine Learning – A Review",
        "Accurate Machine-Learning-Based On-Chip Router Modeling",
        "Efficient Layout Hotspot Detection via Binarized Residual Neural Network Ensemble",
        "Jonathan Bachrach",
        "Meghna Madhusudan",
        "Learning to Select Branching Rules in the DPLL Procedure for Satisfiability",
        "Learning Heuristics for Automated Reasoning through Deep Reinforcement Learning",
        "Learning-Based, Fine-Grain Power Modeling of System-Level Hardware IPs",
        "Hari Govind V. K",
        "Classification and Regression by RandomForest",
        "Alexander Pritzel",
        "Dong Liu and Benjamin Carrión Schäfer",
        "ePlace: Electrostatics-Based Placement Using Fast Fourier Transform and Nesterov’s Method",
        "Anthony Agnesina",
        "Sai Surya Kiran Pentapati",
        "Karthikeyan Natarajan",
        "Cross-layer Optimization for High Speed Adders: A Pareto Driven Machine Learning Approach",
        "Machine-learning based simulated annealer method for high level synthesis design space exploration",
        "Farnoud Farahmand",
        "Tinoosh Mohsenin",
        "Valeria Bertacco",
        "Chip Placement with Deep Reinforcement Learning",
        "and Pierre-Emmanuel Gaillardon",
        "Antonio Jesús Torralba Silgado",
        "Recurrent Relational Networks for Complex Relational Reasoning",
        "Chien-Chia Huang",
        "Shrunk-2-D: A Physical Design Methodology to Build Commercial-Quality Monolithic 3-D ICs",
        "Application of Machine Learning for Optimization of 3-D Integrated Circuits and Systems",
        "Natalia Gimelshein",
        "Evangeline FY Young",
        "Design of analog CMOS integrated circuits",
        "Yakun Sophia Shao",
        "Using ANNs to Size Analog Integrated Circuits",
        "Michael Rotman and Lior Wolf",
        "Machine Learning Based Variation Modeling and Optimization for 3D ICs",
        "NeuroCore: Guiding High-Performance SAT Solvers with Unsat-Core Predictions",
        "Leonardo de Moura",
        "Kourosh Hakhamaneshi",
        "Prateek Bhansali",
        "FASY: a Fuzzy-Logic Based Tool for Analog Synthesis",
        "Mastering the Game of Go without Human Knowledge",
        "Avatarsat: An Auto-Tuning Boolean Sat Solver",
        "Mustapha Slamani",
        "RF Specification Test Compaction Using Learning Machines",
        "Error Moderation in Low-Cost Machine-Learning-Based Analog/RF Testing",
        "Microprocessor Verification via Feedback-Adjusted Markov Models",
        "Learning to Design Circuits",
        "Zi Wang and Benjamin Carrión Schäfer",
        "Natarajan Viswanathan",
        "Mark Po-Hung Lin",
        "and Erick Carvajal Barboza",
        "SATzilla: Portfolio-based Algorithm Selection for SAT",
        "Tetsuaki Matsunawa",
        "Imbalance Aware Lithography Hotspot Detection: a Deep Learning Approach",
        "Mohamed Baker Alawieh",
        "Emre Yolcu and Barnabás Póczos",
        "Nitish Kumar Srivastava",
        "Md Mahfuzur Rahman Siddiquee",
        "Guillaume Sergent"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 87 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Machine Learning for Electronic Design Automation: A Survey, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
